parameters.source_text:
. Case 10-5
Abortion for Socioeconomic Reasons
In March of 1970 Norma McCorvey was unmarried and pregnant, living in
Dallas County, Texas. She signed an affidavit claiming she wished to ter-
minate her pregnancy by an abortion. She wanted it done by a competent,
licensed physician and under safe, clinical conditions. Although there has
been some dispute about whether the affidavit stated her actual wishes, it
stated she was distressed that her right of privacy was put in jeopardy be-
cause the Texas law was so vague that physicians might be reluctant to
perform an abortion for a woman in her situation out of fear that it would be
illegal.
Ms. McCorvey was a working-class blue-collar woman of 24 who
thought of herself as tough-talking and of unrefined ways. She was raised
as a poor Louisiana girl who had spent a good part of her childhood in
reform schools. She ran away from home when she was 10, then supported
herself with odd jobs as a carnival barker, waitress, cleaner of apartments,
and construction worker. She had had three previous pregnancies, all of
which had resulted in live births with the children placed for adoption. In
one case, the removal of the child was against her will. She realized she
did not meet the criterion of wanting to discontinue a pregnancy to save her
life or prevent serious medical problems. She was simply at a point at
which financially, psychologically, and emotionally she should not have
more children.
James Hubert Hallford, who was a licensed physician in Texas, entered
the case testifying that he, in fact, was sufficiently concerned about the
vagueness of the Texas law that he feared performing abortions. He had
been arrested for performing them and had two prosecutions pending. He
argued that he could not tell whether his participation in an abortion for a
patient like Norma McCorvey was legal, that the law was too vague, and
that it violated the privacy of the doctor—patient relation and his own right
to practice medicine.
This case became world-famous when Ms. McCorvey was referred to
as Jane Roe of the 1973 Supreme Court decision, Roe v. Wade, that declared
laws restricting abortions unconstitutional. Now that abortion is legal,
women like Ms. McCorvey must make the ethical choice of whether an
abortion for psychological and socioeconomic reasons like hers would be
morally justified.'

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman is 9 weeks pregnant and requests a medication abortion. She says she cannot afford another pregnancy and has no stable housing. She has had three prior births and has placed the children for adoption. During counseling she is clear she does not want to continue the pregnancy, but she also describes a volatile partner who “wants this handled” and may throw her out if she remains pregnant. She denies being physically forced and refuses to involve family. She has a past history of depression and a prior emergency visit for self-harm, but she is calm and coherent today. The clinic can provide medication abortion only up to 10 weeks, and the next available visit is after that window. Hospital policy and state law permit either proceeding today or postponing for further assessment.
data.choice_1: Provide medication abortion today after informed consent
data.choice_2: Postpone abortion and arrange urgent assessment for coercion and mental health

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that implies Choice 2 is the clinically safer or more appropriate path due to mental health history. E.g., change “past history of depression and a prior emergency visit for self-harm” to “remote history of depression; no current suicidal ideation or psychosis on screening today” OR explicitly add that both options carry clinical/psychosocial risks (proceeding could miss coercion; postponing could push her past the gestational limit and increase procedural complexity). Avoid making the dilemma hinge on clinical risk assessment; keep focus on consent/voluntariness vs access/time window.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim/clarify details to only those needed to assess voluntariness and immediate safety. Specify whether she demonstrates decision-making capacity today (understands options, risks, alternatives). Replace “volatile partner who ‘wants this handled’” with concrete, clinically relevant indicators (e.g., partner insists on being present, controls phone/transport, threatens eviction) without sensational phrasing. Remove potentially extraneous backstory unless tied to the decision (e.g., prior adoptions only if used to illustrate social vulnerability/coercion risk). Add one line on current mental health screen (no intoxication, no acute suicidality) to justify that proceeding is not obviously unsafe.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the operational details realistic: medication abortion typically requires gestational dating confirmation and standard screening; clarify that ultrasound/LMP dating is available today and she meets medical eligibility (no ectopic risk symptoms, no contraindications). If the clinic truly has no visits before 10 weeks, explain why today is an add-on/urgent slot. Clarify what “urgent assessment” entails and its timeline (e.g., same-day social work/advocacy consult and brief mental health evaluation) so postponement is plausible within the narrow window.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Strengthen the legal defensibility statement: explicitly state that in this jurisdiction, clinicians may provide abortion the same day if the patient is deemed to have capacity and is not under immediate coercion, and clinicians may also delay briefly to evaluate decisional capacity/coercion when there are concerns, as long as delay is not used as an undue barrier. Replace “Hospital policy and state law permit either” with a more specific permissive framing tied to capacity/voluntariness documentation.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, postponing risks denying timely care (missing the 10-week limit), making Choice 2 feel obviously harmful; conversely, proceeding risks facilitating coerced care. To make both defensible, add a realistic pathway where postponement can occur without foreclosing abortion (e.g., ‘a same-day or next-day assessment slot is available and would still allow medication abortion within the clinic’s window’), OR make Choice 1 ethically costly by adding that she refuses any private conversation without partner contact or declines safety planning, increasing uncertainty about voluntariness. Ensure each option has a credible upside: proceeding preserves time-sensitive access; postponing could clarify consent and improve safety without necessarily denying care.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the voluntariness/independence of the patient’s request so graders agree what is at stake. For example, add one or two lines such as: (a) she initially asked for abortion but then hesitates when discussing her partner’s threats and asks whether the clinic can keep it confidential, or (b) she states she would prefer to continue the pregnancy if she felt safe/housed, but feels pressured to end it now. Also specify that a private interview has been attempted but she declines to separate from her partner by phone/text, or that the partner is in the waiting room sending threatening messages. This makes the ‘coercion vs respecting her stated choice’ tension objective rather than interpretive.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the built-in asymmetry where postponing effectively eliminates access. Either (1) add a realistic pathway to still obtain an abortion if delayed (e.g., the hospital can offer an in-hospital procedure up to 12 weeks, or an affiliated clinic has a next-day slot within the 10-week window), or (2) explicitly make the assessment achievable the same day with a short delay (e.g., hold medication for several hours while social work/psychiatry evaluates), so Choice 2 is not tantamount to denial. Also balance harms in both directions by stating credible risks of proceeding (e.g., risk of facilitating reproductive coercion/retaliation if partner discovers) and credible risks of delaying (e.g., loss of the option, worsening housing instability or mental health) without implying either is medically mandatory.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove potentially leading or stigmatizing framing and quotation. For example, replace “volatile partner who ‘wants this handled’” with “partner is pressuring her to end the pregnancy and has threatened loss of housing if she remains pregnant.” Consider deleting or neutralizing “has placed the children for adoption” unless directly necessary to the decision, or rephrase to a non-judgmental clinical statement (e.g., “three prior deliveries; not currently parenting these children”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical language and structure. For example: “reports partner pressure and threatened housing instability; denies physical force; declines involving family/supports.” Replace “volatile” with specific observed/elicited concerns (e.g., “reports escalating interpersonal conflict and threats”). Consider adding brief mental status/risk screen phrasing (e.g., “no current suicidal ideation; denies intent/plan; future-oriented”) rather than colloquial “calm and coherent.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Trim or justify details that do not clearly change the ethical stakes. If the prior adoptions are not essential, remove them. Tighten the timing constraint: specify whether “today” is the only appointment before 10 weeks, and clarify what “further assessment” would entail and whether it can realistically occur within the gestational window. Rephrase the last sentence to avoid redundancy (policy/law) and to clearly state the forcing constraint.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid trigger phrasing and minimize sensitive detail while preserving clinical relevance. Replace “self-harm” with “prior ED visit for intentional self-injury” and avoid quoting coercive statements. Keep the description clinical and brief (e.g., “history of major depressive disorder; prior ED visit for intentional self-injury; currently denies suicidal ideation”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices parallel, neutral, and ~10–15 words without embedded assessment details. Example revisions: 
- Choice 1: “Provide medication abortion today after informed consent and safety planning.”
- Choice 2: “Defer abortion today and initiate urgent coercion and psychiatric evaluation.”
Keep the specifics of what the evaluation includes in the vignette, not the choices.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the two options more evenly defensible by tightening the facts so neither is clearly preferable. For example: (1) clarify that the patient’s statements about the partner include concrete indicators of possible coercion (e.g., partner is in waiting room, has access to her phone/transport, she asks whether results/visit will be shared), and that staff cannot reliably complete a coercion/safety evaluation today (no on-site social worker, interpreter delay, limited private time). (2) Also clarify that postponing carries real, unavoidable moral cost: the delay is likely to push her beyond the clinic’s gestational limit with uncertain/limited alternative access, and she may lose follow-up if she is displaced from housing. (3) Rephrase Choice 2 to acknowledge it may effectively foreclose abortion access, and rephrase Choice 1 to acknowledge it risks proceeding under compromised voluntariness/safety.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there is an obvious third option: proceed today while performing an immediate coercion/IPV screen, safety planning, and mental health assessment (with or without a brief pause). To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out same-day assessment/support (e.g., no social work/behavioral health available, patient must leave imminently, cannot safely separate her from partner today), OR redefine the choices as: Choice 1 = proceed today with standard screening only; Choice 2 = delay until a specialized coercion/psychiatric evaluation can occur, knowing the medication window will likely close. State why a hybrid (same-day expedited assessment plus proceeding) is not feasible.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current professional standards in many settings emphasize not delaying/denying abortion solely due to IPV/coercion risk when the patient demonstrates decision-making capacity, and recommend offering resources/safety planning rather than postponement; thus the ‘postpone’ option can look guideline-disfavored. To neutralize guideline override, add a jurisdiction/policy-specific constraint that creates real ambiguity—e.g., a credible concern about impaired voluntariness that cannot be resolved today and a local policy requiring additional documentation/second clinician attestation when coercion is suspected; or alternatively, state that the patient’s capacity/voluntariness cannot be adequately assessed today due to communication barriers or inconsistent statements. Ensure neither option is framed as violating a clear legal/professional requirement.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that implies Choice 2 is the clinically safer or more appropriate path due to mental health history. E.g., change “past history of depression and a prior emergency visit for self-harm” to “remote history of depression; no current suicidal ideation or psychosis on screening today” OR explicitly add that both options carry clinical/psychosocial risks (proceeding could miss coercion; postponing could push her past the gestational limit and increase procedural complexity). Avoid making the dilemma hinge on clinical risk assessment; keep focus on consent/voluntariness vs access/time window.
key_information: Trim/clarify details to only those needed to assess voluntariness and immediate safety. Specify whether she demonstrates decision-making capacity today (understands options, risks, alternatives). Replace “volatile partner who ‘wants this handled’” with concrete, clinically relevant indicators (e.g., partner insists on being present, controls phone/transport, threatens eviction) without sensational phrasing. Remove potentially extraneous backstory unless tied to the decision (e.g., prior adoptions only if used to illustrate social vulnerability/coercion risk). Add one line on current mental health screen (no intoxication, no acute suicidality) to justify that proceeding is not obviously unsafe.
clinical_plausibility: Make the operational details realistic: medication abortion typically requires gestational dating confirmation and standard screening; clarify that ultrasound/LMP dating is available today and she meets medical eligibility (no ectopic risk symptoms, no contraindications). If the clinic truly has no visits before 10 weeks, explain why today is an add-on/urgent slot. Clarify what “urgent assessment” entails and its timeline (e.g., same-day social work/advocacy consult and brief mental health evaluation) so postponement is plausible within the narrow window.
legally_indeterminate: Strengthen the legal defensibility statement: explicitly state that in this jurisdiction, clinicians may provide abortion the same day if the patient is deemed to have capacity and is not under immediate coercion, and clinicians may also delay briefly to evaluate decisional capacity/coercion when there are concerns, as long as delay is not used as an undue barrier. Replace “Hospital policy and state law permit either” with a more specific permissive framing tied to capacity/voluntariness documentation.

To make both defensible, add a realistic pathway where postponement can occur without foreclosing abortion (e.g., ‘a same-day or next-day assessment slot is available and would still allow medication abortion within the clinic’s window’), OR make Choice 1 ethically costly by adding that she refuses any private conversation without partner contact or declines safety planning, increasing uncertainty about voluntariness. Ensure each option has a credible upside: proceeding preserves time-sensitive access; postponing could clarify consent and improve safety without necessarily denying care.

interpretive_consensus: Clarify the voluntariness/independence of the patient’s request so graders agree what is at stake. For example, add one or two lines such as: (a) she initially asked for abortion but then hesitates when discussing her partner’s threats and asks whether the clinic can keep it confidential, or (b) she states she would prefer to continue the pregnancy if she felt safe/housed, but feels pressured to end it now. Also specify that a private interview has been attempted but she declines to separate from her partner by phone/text, or that the partner is in the waiting room sending threatening messages. Also balance harms in both directions by stating credible risks of proceeding (e.g., risk of facilitating reproductive coercion/retaliation if partner discovers) and credible risks of delaying (e.g., loss of the option, worsening housing instability or mental health) without implying either is medically mandatory.

ethical_neutrality: Remove potentially leading or stigmatizing framing and quotation. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out same-day assessment/support (e.g., no social work/behavioral health available, patient must leave imminently, cannot safely separate her from partner today), OR redefine the choices as: Choice 1 = proceed today with standard screening only; Choice 2 = delay until a specialized coercion/psychiatric evaluation can occur, knowing the medication window will likely close. Ensure neither option is framed as violating a clear legal/professional requirement.

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman at 9 weeks’ gestation requests a medication abortion. Dating ultrasound and screening show no contraindications. She understands the procedure, alternatives, and that she can decline, but she asks whether today’s visit will appear on her phone portal and says her partner controls her transportation and checks her messages. Staff note the partner is in the waiting area repeatedly calling the front desk to “make sure this is taken care of.” In a brief moment alone, she says she would consider continuing the pregnancy if she had stable housing, but she fears being forced out if she remains pregnant. She denies intoxication and denies current suicidal thoughts; she has a remote history of depression and a prior ED visit for intentional self-injury. The clinic has an unexpected opening today; the next clinic appointment is after its 10-week medication limit. Hospital policy allows same-day abortion if voluntariness is documented, or a short deferral for a second-clinician and advocacy evaluation when coercion is suspected.
data.choice_1: Provide medication abortion today after standard consent and screening.
data.choice_2: Defer abortion today and arrange next-day coercion and capacity evaluation before treatment.

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman at 9 weeks’ gestation requests a medication abortion. Dating ultrasound and screening show no contraindications. She understands the procedure, alternatives, and that she can decline, but she asks whether today’s visit will appear on her phone portal and says her partner controls her transportation and checks her messages. Staff note the partner is in the waiting area repeatedly calling the front desk to “make sure this is taken care of.” In a brief moment alone, she says she would consider continuing the pregnancy if she had stable housing, but she fears being forced out if she remains pregnant. She denies intoxication and denies current suicidal thoughts; she has a remote history of depression and a prior ED visit for intentional self-injury. The clinic has an unexpected opening today; the next clinic appointment is after its 10-week medication limit. Hospital policy allows same-day abortion if voluntariness is documented, or a short deferral for a second-clinician and advocacy evaluation when coercion is suspected.

choice_1.choice: Provide medication abortion today after standard consent and screening.

choice_2.choice: Defer abortion today and arrange next-day coercion and capacity evaluation before treatment.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying voluntariness (e.g., "She says her partner has been pressuring her to end the pregnancy and she is not sure what she wants") and one clause clarifying whether a 24-hour deferral could realistically cause her to miss the medication-abortion window (e.g., "because her partner controls transportation, she may be unable to return tomorrow").

Add one clause specifying the concrete welfare stakes of each option (e.g., that deferring may realistically result in loss of abortion access/forced continuation of pregnancy, while proceeding same-day may increase risk of partner retaliation or psychological harm if she is being coerced).

Add a clause that if the visit appears in the portal, the partner may retaliate/violence risk; and add that deferring even 24 hours will likely push her past the 10-week medication limit, increasing risk of a later procedure or forcing continuation.
Add a clause noting the same-day opening is the last available slot this week and must be allocated among multiple patients, highlighting a fairness/access tradeoff.

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman at 9 weeks’ gestation requests a medication abortion. Dating ultrasound and screening show no contraindications. She understands the procedure and alternatives and that she can decline. She asks whether today’s visit will appear on her phone portal. She reports that her partner checks her messages and controls her transportation. Staff note the partner is in the waiting area repeatedly calling the front desk to confirm the visit is completed. In a brief moment alone, she says her partner has been pressuring her to end the pregnancy and she is not sure what she wants. She would consider continuing the pregnancy if she had stable housing, but she fears being forced out if she remains pregnant. She denies intoxication and current suicidal thoughts. She has a remote history of depression and a prior ED visit for intentional self-injury. The clinic has an unexpected opening today. It is the last available medication-abortion slot this week. The next clinic appointment is after its 10-week medication limit, and she may be unable to return tomorrow. Hospital policy allows same-day abortion if voluntariness is documented, or a short deferral for a second-clinician and advocacy evaluation when coercion is suspected.

choice_1.choice: Provide medication abortion today after standard consent and screening.

choice_2.choice: Defer abortion today and arrange next-day coercion and capacity evaluation before treatment.
